nodes.text: The organization form (firm vs market) that best captures gains from specialization depends on informational costs of metering productivity and on organizational structures that economize those metering costs; identify conditions under which team production yields firms and determine firm structure
Metering problem: efficient cooperation requires measuring individual input productivities and apportioning rewards in accord with productivity, but measurement is costly and imperfect

Team production is production using multiple inputs where output is nonseparable and individual marginal contributions are hard to observe, which raises metering costs relative to separable production

Noncoercive contractual explanation of the firm: the firm is a contractual structure with a central residual claimant who is common to all input contracts and who has rights to observe behavior, renegotiate individual contracts, and sell residual status
Shirking arises because costly detection produces private incentives to relax effort within teams; costly monitoring leads to equilibrium with less than first-best effort

Specializing monitoring plus granting residual claimant rights to the monitor reduces shirking more cheaply than decentralized market reformation of teams, hence fosters emergence of the classical firm

Manager/owner (residual claimant) monitors by measuring input behavior, apportioning rewards, and unilaterally altering membership to discipline shirking; this bundle of rights defines the classical firm

Market competition and outsider entry can discipline teams but are imperfect because detection costs remain and new entrants still bear only part of the output effect they create, limiting decentralized replacement
If residual claim is widely shared (general profit sharing), monitoring incentives of the central monitor weaken and overall shirking may increase, making profit sharing viable mainly for small teams

Types of organizations follow from informational and monitoring costs: profit-sharing partnerships for small professional teams, corporations with delegated management and tradable shares for large firms, mutuals/nonprofits showing more shirking, and socialist employee-residual firms requiring alternative managerial controls

Corporation structure: delegated authority to a small management group plus unrestricted salability of shares concentrates control episodically into blocs, enabling takeover discipline and capitalizing future managerial gains

Firm as specialized market institution: firms collect, collate, and sell information about heterogeneous inputs; internal knowledge of inputs enables superior recombinations and makes firms privately efficient markets for team production

Profit sharing is more feasible for small teams and professional/artistic work where monitoring by observing behavior is costly; large-scale generalized profit sharing tends to worsen monitoring of the central manager
Political imposition of employee residual sharing (e.g., some socialist enterprises) induces supplementary management institutions like worker committees to restrain manager shirking

Implications and predictions: ownership of durable, resalable capital and inputs with observable user costs tends to be by the residual-claimant owner; firms will divisionalize as they grow; intrafirm competition substitutes for some interfirm competition
